byline.contributor: Lizette Alvarez reported from Miami, and Manny Fernandez from Houston.
byline.original: By LIZETTE ALVAREZ and MANNY FERNANDEZ

abstract: Republican presidential candidacies of Cuban-Americans Ted Cruz and Marco Rubio represents significant moment in American politics, with two Hispanics figuring among race's top contenders and competing fiercely with one another; increasingly harsh positions on immigration floated by many Republican aspirants conflict with many Hispanics' expectations of their rise to political prominence and may complicate Cruz and Rubio's chances to win.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Cruz and Mr. Rubio, conservative Cuban-American candidates who make a point of playing down their ethnic identity, have differed on defense, immigration and other issues.

headline.main: Marco Rubio and Ted Cruz Diverge in Approach to Their Hispanic Identity
headline.print_headline: 2 Latino Candidates at Odds, Heritage and Ideology Aside

snippet: Mr. Cruz and Mr. Rubio, conservative Cuban-American candidates who make a point of playing down their ethnic identity, have differed on defense, immigration and other issues.
